dialogue_metadata.inferred_vibe: Analytical and informative discussion about financial markets and current events.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The S&P 500 just had its best 52-day streak ever, and I'm honestly struggling to wrap my head around it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The S&P five hundred just had its best fifty two-day streak ever, and I'm honestly struggling to wrap my head around it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Wednesday, the S&P 500 saw its best 50-day streak in its history even as a massive wave of protests in the aftermath of the death of George Floyd continued to unfold across the country and experts looked ahead to a dismal May unemployment rate on the order of 20%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? With everything happening—the protests, the unemployment projections around 21%—it feels like the market's in a totally different universe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? With everything happening-the protests, the unemployment projections around twenty one percent-it feels like the market's in a totally different universe.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Wednesday, the S&P 500 saw its best 50-day streak in its history even as a massive wave of protests in the aftermath of the death of George Floyd continued to unfold across the country and experts looked ahead to a dismal May unemployment rate on the order of 20%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But this isn't new. Like, in 1968, after Dr. King was assassinated and all that turmoil, the S&P still gained 9%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But this isn't new. Like, in nineteen sixty eight, after Dr. King was assassinated and all that turmoil, the S&P still gained nine percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1968, the year Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated, the S&P gained 8%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and even after 9/11, stocks were up more than 2% just three months later. It's wild how detached markets can be from reality sometimes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and even after nine over eleven, stocks were up more than two percent just three months later. It's wild how detached markets can be from reality sometimes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While stocks ended 2001 down 13%, they ended the three months following the September 11 terror attacks up more than 1%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Jim Cramer said it best this week—the market has no conscience. Investors are just focused on making money, period.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Jim Cramer said it best this week-the market has no conscience. Investors are just focused on making money, period.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the end of the day, the market has no conscience. Investors are simply trying to make money, CNBCs Jim Cramer said this week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And right now they're betting on a fast recovery, ignoring the pandemic, protests, politics… all of it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And right now they're betting on a fast recovery, ignoring the pandemic, protests, politics... all of it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors are continuing to ignore the three Pspandemic, protests and politicsand are instead focused on what increasingly is being interpreted as a quicker and better than expected recovery in the economy, David Donabedian, chief investment officer at CIBC Private Wealth Management, told the Wall Street Journal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But is that optimism justified? I mean, the Fed's report showed most businesses are still pretty pessimistic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But is that optimism justified? I mean, the Fed's report showed most businesses are still pretty pessimistic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserves most recent report about the state of the economy, for instance, indicated that even though all 50 states are beginning to take their first steps toward reopening, most businesses are still pessimistic about the pace of economic recovery.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And the IMF thinks bank profits could be down through 2025. That's a long haul.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And the I M F thinks bank profits could be down through twenty twenty five. That's a long haul.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And last month, the IMF predicted that banks will suffer sharp declines in profits through 2025, and that substantial action will be needed to make up for earnings shortfalls caused by the coronavirus crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So the market's pricing in a rebound before the economy even hits bottom. That's risky.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the market's pricing in a rebound before the economy even hits bottom. That's risky.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Markets will price in a recovery well before the economic data bottoms, says Todd Lowenstein, chief equity strategist at HighMark Capital Management. The market tends to be ahead of the actual data itself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. We might not have seen the worst yet, even with the S&P climbing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. We might not have seen the worst yet, even with the S&P climbing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That means that the worst could be yet to come, even though the S&P seems poised to soar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: History shows us markets can rally through chaos, but… it still feels unsettling.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: History shows us markets can rally through chaos, but... it still feels unsettling.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Markets have a long history of looking beyond periods of social or political unrest, even when it seems impossible that stocks could be so divorced from world events.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: No doubt. Let's see if this disconnect holds—or if reality catches up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No doubt. Let's see if this disconnect holds-or if reality catches up.
